SCHEME AND SOLUTION School of Computer Science And Engineering Semester: Sixth Course Title: Cloud Computing Academic year: 2024-25 Course Code: B22EF0604 UNIT ‚Äì I                          Marks

1. a) The common benefits associated with adopting cloud computing are 10 ‚ñ™ Reduced Investments and Proportional Costs ‚ñ™ Increased Scalability ‚ñ™ Increased Availability and Reliability Reduced Investments and Proportional Costs: ‚Ä¢ Similar to a product wholesaler that purchases goods in bulk for lower price points, ‚Äì public cloud providers base their business model on the mass-acquisition of IT resources that are then made available to cloud consumers via attractively priced leasing packages. This opens the door for organizations to gain access to powerful infrastructure without having to purchase it themselves. ‚Ä¢ The most common economic way of investing in cloud-based IT resources is in the reduction or outright elimination of up-front IT investments (hardware & software purchases and ownership costs). ‚Äì This is referred to as Reduced Investments. ‚Ä¢ A cloud‚Äôs Measured Usage characteristic represents a feature-set that allows measured operational expenditures (i.e., directly related to business performance) to replace anticipated capital expenditures. ‚Äì This is referred to as Proportional Costs. ‚Ä¢ In its most basic form, opportunities to decrease costs are derived from the deployment and operation of large-scale data centers by major cloud providers. ‚Ä¢ Such data centers are commonly located in destinations where real estate, IT professionals, and network bandwidth can be obtained at lower costs, resulting in both capital and operational savings. ‚Ä¢ On-demand access to pay-as-you-go computing resources on a short-term basis (such as processors by the hour), and the ability to release these computing resources when they are no longer needed. ‚Ä¢ The perception of having unlimited computing resources that are available on demand, thereby reducing the need to prepare for provisioning. ‚Ä¢ The ability to add or remove IT resources at a fine-grained level, such as modifying available storage disk space by single gigabyte increments. ‚Ä¢ Abstraction of the infrastructure so applications are not locked into devices or locations and can be easily moved if needed. ‚Ä¢ Increased Availability and Reliability: ‚Ä¢ The availability and reliability of IT resources are directly associated with noticeable business benefits. Page | 1 ‚Ä¢ A hallmark of the typical cloud environment is its key ability to provide extensive support for: ‚Ä¢ increasing the availability of a cloud-based IT resource to minimize or even eliminate outages. ‚Ä¢ increasing its reliability so as to minimize the impact of runtime failure conditions. ‚Ä¢  RAS: Reliability, Availability and Serviceability. ‚Ä¢   ‚Äì First used by IBM for their Mainframes (only to hardware). ‚Ä¢

b)      Increased Security Vulnerabilities                          10 Reduced Operational Governance Control Limited Portability Between Cloud Providers Multi-Regional Compliance and Legal Issues Increased Security Vulnerabilities: ‚Ä¢ The moving of business data to the cloud means that the responsibility over data security becomes shared with the cloud provider. ‚Ä¢ The remote usage of IT resources requires an expansion of trust boundaries by the cloud consumer to include the external cloud. ‚Ä¢ It can be difficult to establish a security architecture that spans such a trust boundary without introducing vulnerabilities, ‚Äì unless cloud consumers and cloud providers happen to support the same or compatible security frameworks ‚Äî which is unlikely with public clouds. ‚Ä¢ The overlapping of trust boundaries and the increased exposure of data can provide malicious cloud consumers (human and automated) with greater opportunities to attack IT resources and steal or damage business data. Reduced Operational Governance Control: ‚Ä¢ Cloud consumers are usually allotted a level of governance control that is lower than that over on-premise IT resources. ‚Ä¢ This can introduce risks associated with how the cloud provider operates its cloud, as well as the external connections that are required for communication between the cloud and the cloud consumer. ‚Ä¢ Consider the following examples: ‚ñ™ An unreliable cloud provider may not maintain the guarantees it makes in the SLAs that were published for its cloud services. This can risk the quality of the cloud consumer solutions that rely on these cloud services. ‚ñ™ Longer geographic distances between the cloud consumer and cloud provider can require additional network hops that introduce fluctuating latency and potential bandwidth constraints. Limited Portability Between Cloud Providers: ‚ñ™ Due to a lack of established industry standards within the cloud computing industry, public clouds are commonly exclusive to various extents. ‚ñ™ For cloud consumers that have custom-built solutions with dependencies on these exclusive environments, it can be challenging to move from one cloud provider to another. ‚ñ™ Portability is a measure used to determine the impact of moving cloud consumer IT resources and data between clouds. Page | 2 Multi-Regional Compliance and Legal Issues: ‚Ä¢ Third-party cloud providers will frequently establish data centers in affordable or convenient geographical locations. ‚Ä¢ Cloud consumers will often not be aware of the physical location of their IT resources and data when hosted by public clouds. ‚Ä¢ For some organizations, this can pose serious legal concerns pertaining to industry or government regulations that specify data privacy and storage policies. ‚Ä¢ For example, some UK laws require personal data belonging to UK citizens to be kept within the United Kingdom.

b)    ‚Ä¢ Cloud computing is a model for enabling ubiquitous, convenient, on-demand network 10 access to a shared pool of configurable computing resources (e.g., networks, servers, storage, applications, and services) that can be rapidly provisioned and released with minimal management effort or service provider interaction. This cloud model is composed of five essential characteristics, three service models, and four deployment models. ‚Ä¢ Scaling, from an IT resource perspective, represents the ability of the IT resource to handle i‚Äùncreased or decreased usage demands. Horizontal Scaling: ‚Ä¢ The allocating or releasing of IT resources that are of the same type is referred to as horizontal scaling. ‚Ä¢ The horizontal allocation of resources is referred to as scaling out. ‚Ä¢ The horizontal releasing of resources is referred to as scaling in. ‚Ä¢ Horizontal scaling is a common form of scaling within cloud environments. Page | 3 Vertical Scaling: ‚Ä¢ When an existing IT resource is replaced by another with higher or lower capacity, vertical scaling is considered to have occurred. ‚Ä¢ The replacing of an IT resource with another that has a higher capacity is referred to as scaling up. ‚Ä¢ The replacing an IT resource with another that has a lower capacity is considered scaling down. ‚Ä¢ Vertical scaling is less common in cloud environments due to the downtime (stoppage) required while the replacement is taking place.

3. a) Network Storage Interfaces:                                      10 ‚Ä¢ Legacy network storage most commonly falls under the category of network storage interfaces. ‚Ä¢ It includes storage devices in compliance with industry standard protocols, such as Small Computer System Interface (SCSI) for storage blocks and the Server Message Block (SMB), Common Internet file System (CIFS), and Network File System (NFS) for file and network storage. ‚Ä¢ File storage entails storing individual data in separate files that can be different sizes and formats and organized into folders and subfolders. Page | 4 ‚Ä¢ Original files are often replaced by the new files that are created when data has been modified. ‚Ä¢ Storage processing levels and thresholds for file allocation are usually determined by the file system itself. ‚Ä¢ Block storage requires data to be in a fixed format (known as a data block), which is the smallest unit that can be stored and accessed and the storage format closest to hardware. ‚Ä¢ Using either the Logical Unit Number (LUN) or virtual volume block-level storage will typically have better performance than file-level storage. Object Storage Interfaces: ‚Ä¢ Various types of data can be referenced and stored as Web resources. ‚Ä¢ This is referred to as object storage, which is based on technologies that can support a range of data and media types. ‚Ä¢ Cloud Storage Device mechanisms that implement this interface can typically be accessed via REST or Web service-based (SOAP) cloud services using HTTP as the prime protocol. ‚Ä¢ The Storage Networking Industry Association‚Äôs Cloud Data Management Interface (SNIA‚Äôs CDMI) supports the use of object storage interfaces. ‚Ä¢ Each of these data storage levels is commonly associated with a certain type of technical interface which corresponds to a particular type of cloud storage device and cloud storage service used to expose its API. Network Storage Interfaces: ‚Ä¢ Legacy network storage most commonly falls under the category of network storage interfaces. ‚Ä¢ It includes storage devices in compliance with industry standard protocols, such as Small Computer System Interface (SCSI) for storage blocks and the Server Message Block (SMB), Common Internet file System (CIFS), and Network File System (NFS) for file and network storage. Database Storage Interfaces: ‚Ä¢ Cloud storage device mechanisms based on database storage interfaces typically support a query language in addition to basic storage operations. ‚Ä¢ Storage management is carried out using a standard API or an administrative user interface. ‚Ä¢ This classification of storage interface is divided into two main categories according to storage structure, as follows: Relational Data Storage: ‚Ä¢ Working with relational storage commonly involves the use of the industry standard Structured Query Language (SQL). ‚Ä¢ A cloud storage device mechanism implemented using relational data storage could be based on any number of commercially available database products, such as IBM DB2, Oracle Database, Microsoft SQL Server, and MySQL. ‚Ä¢

4. a) Explanation of the basic mechanics of internetworking and a generic view of the 10 internet reference model and protocol stack ‚Ä¢ The concept of the Internet was based on a decentralized/distributed provisioning and management model. ‚Ä¢ ISPs can freely deploy, operate, and manage their networks in addition to selecting partner ISPs for interconnection. ‚Ä¢ Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers (ICANN) supervise and coordinate Internet communications. ‚Ä¢ Governmental and regulatory laws order the service provisioning conditions for organizations and ISPs both within and outside of national borders. ‚Ä¢ Worldwide connectivity is enabled through a hierarchical topology composed of Tiers 1, 2, and 3. ‚Ä¢ The core Tier 1 is made of large-scale, international cloud providers that oversee massive interconnected global networks, which are connected to Tier 2‚Äôs large regional providers. ‚Ä¢ The interconnected ISPs of Tier 2 connect with Tier 1 providers, as well as the local ISPs of Tier 3. ‚Ä¢ Cloud consumers and cloud providers can connect directly using a Tier 1 provider, since any operational ISP can enable Internet connection. ‚Ä¢ Two fundamental components used to construct the internetworking architecture are: ‚ñ™ Connectionless Packet Switching (Datagram Networks) ‚ñ™ Router-Based Interconnectivity A generic view of the Internet reference model and protocol stack ‚ñ™ Page | 7 Physical Network: ‚Ä¢ IP packets are transmitted through underlying physical networks that connect adjacent nodes, such as Ethernet, ATM network and so on. ‚Ä¢ Physical networks comprise a data link layer that controls data transfer between neighboring nodes, and a physical layer that transmits data bits through both wired and wireless media. Transport Layer Protocol: ‚Ä¢ IP Transport layer protocols, such as the Transmission Control Protocol (TCP) and User Datagram Protocol (UDP), use the IP to provide standardized, end-to-end communication support that facilitates the navigation of data packets across the Internet. Application Layer Protocol: ‚Ä¢ Protocols such as HTTP, SMTP for e-mail, BitTorrent for P2P, use transport layer protocols to standardize and enable specific data packet transferring methods over the Internet. ‚Ä¢ Many other protocols also fulfill application-centric requirements and use either TCP/IP or UDP as their primary method of data transferring across the Internet and LANs.

b) Operating System-Based Virtualization:                           10 ‚Ä¢ Operating system-based virtualization is the installation of virtualization software in a pre-existing operating system, which is called the host operating system. ‚Ä¢ Virtualization software translates hardware IT resources that require unique software for operation into virtualized IT resources that are compatible with a range of operating systems. ‚Ä¢ Since the host operating system is a complete operating system in itself, many operating system-based services that are available as administration tools can be used to manage the physical host. ‚Ä¢ Examples of such services include: ‚ñ™ Backup and Recovery ‚ñ™ Integration to Directory Services ‚ñ™ Security Management Page | 8 ‚Ä¢ Operating system-based virtualization can introduce demands and issues related to performance overhead such as: ‚ñ™ The host operating system consumes CPU, memory, and other hardware IT resources. ‚ñ™ Hardware-related calls from guest operating systems need to traverse several layers to and from the hardware, which decreases overall performance. ‚ñ™ Licenses are usually required for host operating systems, in addition to individual licenses for each of their guest operating systems. A concern with operating system-based virtualization is the processing overhead required to run the virtualization software and host operating systems Hardware-Based Virtualization: ‚Ä¢ Hardware-based virtualization represents the installation of virtualization software directly on the physical host hardware so as to bypass the host operating system. ‚Ä¢ Allowing the virtual servers to interact with hardware without requiring intermediary action from the host operating system generally makes hardware-based virtualization more efficient. ‚Ä¢ Virtualization software is typically referred to as a hypervisor for this type of processing. ‚Ä¢ A hypervisor has a simple user-interface that requires a negligible amount of storage space. ‚Ä¢ It exists as a thin layer of software that handles hardware management functions to establish a virtualization management layer. ‚Ä¢ One of the main issues of hardware-based virtualization concerns compatibility with hardware devices. Page | 9 ‚Ä¢ The virtualization layer is designed to communicate directly with the host hardware, meaning all of the associated device drivers and support software need to be compatible with the hypervisor. ‚Ä¢ Hardware device drivers may not be as available to hypervisor platforms as they are to operating systems. ‚Ä¢ Host management and administration features may further not include the range of advanced functions that are common to operating systems.

c) Polling Agent:                                                   5 ‚Ä¢ A polling agent is a processing module that collects cloud service usage data by polling IT resources. ‚Ä¢ This type of cloud service monitor is commonly used to periodically monitor IT resource status, such as uptime and downtime. ‚Ä¢ ‚ÄòPolling‚Äô is the continuous checking of other programs or devices by one program or device to see what state they are in, usually to see whether they are still connected or want to communicate. ‚Ä¢ Cloud uptime is the amount of time that a cloud service hosted by a cloud provider is accessible to end users. ‚Ä¢ Cloud downtime is a period of time during which cloud services are unavailable. ‚Ä¢ It can be caused by a number of different factors: Loss of power, Network connectivity issues, data center going offline for maintenance (scheduled or unscheduled)

c) State Management Database:A state management database is a specialized database (or a 5 database-like storage) used to store and retrieve application state data, which is information about the current state of an application or user session. ‚Ä¢ A state management database is a storage device that is used to temporarily persist state data for software programs. ‚Ä¢ As an alternative to caching state data in memory, software programs can off-load state data to the database in order to reduce the amount of runtime memory they consume. ‚Ä¢ By doing so, the software programs and the surrounding infrastructure are more scalable. ‚Ä¢ State management databases are commonly used by cloud services, especially those involved in long-running runtime activities. Page | 12 During the lifespan of a cloud service instance it may be required to remain stateful and keep state data cached in memory, even when idle. By deferring state data to a state repository, the cloud service is able to transition to a stateless condition (or a partially stateless condition), thereby temporarily freeing system resources.

b) A failover system is configured to automatically switch over to a redundant or standby IT 10 resource instance whenever the currently active IT resource becomes unavailable. Failover systems are commonly used for mission-critical programs and reusable services that can introduce a single point of failure for multiple applications. A failover system can span more than one geographical region so that each location hosts one or more redundant implementations of the same IT resource Active-Active: ‚Ä¢ In an active-active configuration, redundant implementations of the IT resource actively serve the workload synchronously. ‚Ä¢ Load balancing among active instances is required. ‚Ä¢ When a failure is detected, the failed instance is removed from the load balancing scheduler. ‚Ä¢ Whichever IT resource remains operational when a failure is detected takes over the processing. Page | 14 Active-Passive: ‚Ä¢ In an active-passive configuration, a standby or inactive implementation is activated to take over the processing from the IT resource that becomes unavailable, and the corresponding workload is redirected to the instance taking over the operation. ‚Ä¢ Some failover systems are designed to redirect workloads to active IT resources that rely on specialized load balancers that detect failure conditions and exclude failed IT resource instances from the workload distribution. This type of failover system is suitable for IT resources that do not require execution state management and provide stateless processing capabilities. The failover system monitors the operational status of Cloud Service A. The Cloud Service A implementation acting as the active instance is receiving cloud service consumer requests. The Cloud Service A implementation acting as the active instance encounters a failure that is detected by the failover system, which subsequently activates the inactive Cloud Service A implementation and redirects the workload toward it. The newly invoked Cloud Service A implementation now assumes the role of active instance. Page | 15 The failed Cloud Service A implementation is recovered or replicated an operational cloud service, and is now positioned as the standby instance, while the previously invoked Cloud Service A continues to serve as the active instance.
